description: First at end of 16th century; borrowed from Middle French estimer, from Latin aestimō (“to value, rate, weigh, estimate”); see estimate and aim, an older word, partly a doublet of esteem.

examples: We hold her in high esteem.

verbs.description: esteem (third-person singular simple present esteems, present participle esteeming, simple past and past participle esteemed)

entries.meaning: To set a high value on; to regard with respect or reverence.
examples: You talk kindlier: we esteem you for it.

entries.meaning: To regard something as valuable; to prize.
To look upon something in a particular way.
examples: Mary is an esteemed member of the community.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To judge; to estimate; to appraise
examples: The Earth, which I esteem unable to reflect the rays of the Sun.
